reviewText: Jurassic Park: The Franchise CollectionJurassic Park (1993)126min [PG-13] ****1/2Director: Steven Spielberg.Screenwriters: Michael Crichton and David Koepp.Cast: Sam Neill, Laura Dern Jeff Goldblum, Richard Attenborough, Bob Peck, Martin Ferrero, Joseph Mazzello, Ariana Richards, Samuel L. Jackson, Wayne Knight, B.D. Wong.Review: Billionaire John Hammond (Attenborough) invites paleontologist Dr. Grant (Neill), and paleobotanist Dr. Sattler (Dern), while the "bloodsucking lawyer" invites "rock star" mathematician Ian Malcom (Goldblum) to inspect an amusement park located off the island of Isla Nublar. Now, this isn't Six Flags or Disneyland here, but an amusement park populated by genetically engineered dinosaurs. The latter is actually delivered in an intriguing way that actually makes you believe `hey, that sounds possible!' Essentially, InGen scientists have taken dino-DNA that has been preserved inside amber-encased mosquitoes along with frog DNA to complete the missing strand. Viola! Dinosaurs!The eccentric billionaire is so convinced that this is just some regular walk in the park that he even invites his own grandchildren to tag along. Soon, all hell breaks loose when a disgruntled Jurassic Park employee (Knight) disables the security system so he can successfully steal some dino embryos. Now, the experts, and the grandchildren need to fight for their lives against a carnivorous T-Rex and some wily raptors. The film is loaded with some truly magical and/or awe-inspiring moments like the first revelation of the dinosaurs, or the first attack of the ferocious T-Rex. This is all of course heightened by the wonderful musical score by John Williams and the near-seamless animatronics and computer effects that deservingly took home the Oscar that year. Spielberg lays on the suspense, and action with some genuine moments of chills and thrills. Not to mention, a good sense of humor."Jurassic Park" became a phenomenon in 1993, and it would not only spawn two sequels, but it also paved the way to such films like, "Jumanji," Mighty Joe Young," and an Americanized "Godzilla," to name a few. Those films, however, could never touch the wonderment, and excitement that "Jurassic Park" was able to conjure up ... and still able to possess today. Now, this shouldn't be confused with the greatness of "Jaws," but this is one hell of an entertaining movie.The Lost World: Jurassic Park (1997)134min. [PG-13] ***1/2Director: Steven SpielbergScreenwriter: David KoeppCast: Jeff Goldblum, Julianne Moore, Pete Postlethwaite, Arliss Howard, Richard Attenborough, Vince Vaughn, Vanessa Lee Chester, Peter Stormare, Harvey Jasoon, Richard Schiff, Thomas F. Duffy, Joseph Mazzello, Ariana Richards.Review: Disappointing follow-up to mega-hit "Jurassic Park" reveals that there was a second island. Apparently, Hammond would have the dinosaurs bred on Isla Sorna, and then shipped 80 miles to the park. Without any assistance, "nature has found a way," and the dinosaurs are flourishing in this "lost world". So, Hammond now wants to send a new team to investigate the dinosaurs' progress. From the start, there are some obvious cracks in the logic being displayed in the film. In the first film, we were shown that the dinosaurs are born, and engineered at the park. So essentially, they now want us believe that the dinosaurs were born at the park, but shipped to site B for breeding, only to be returned to the park sometime later. Seems impractical and expensive, if you ask me. Why didn't the engineering and breeding happen all on one island?That aside, Jeff Goldblum returns as a now humiliated Ian Malcolm, who must go (along with a small team) to this second island to rescue his paleontologist girlfriend (Moore). This is another illogical set-up. As I stated earlier, Hammond wanted a team of four to investigate the dinosaurs on site B (where there is no barricades), and wanted Ian Malcolm - the one character he not only disliked from the first film, but who he also thought was unqualified - to go. This contrived sequel is filled with some truly dumb characters that refuse to understand their deadly surroundings, and Malcolm gets an unnecessary and unexplained black offspring. The latter is the most puzzling addition. In the first film Malcolm states he has three children, and apparently multiple ex-wives. Now, all we get is that he has a 13 year-old black daughter that can defeat a velociraptor using ridiculously complicated gymnastic moves. Oookay.We also get the spectacle of a T-Rex running amok in the streets of San Diego during the film's climax even though little logic is implored in doing so. How exactly does the T-Rex devour the entire crew of the boat, and then lock itself back into the cargo hold? This is certainly one messy sequel that is really only saved by the still stunning visual effects, Goldblum's likeability and comedic timing, as well as some exciting edge of your seat action scenes. You can find a lot to be entertained by as long as you chuck your brain at the door, and try not to closely scrutinize things like plot and character motivations. That is easier said than done, however.Jurassic Park III (2001)93min. [PG-13] ****Director: Joe Johnston ("Honey, I Shrunk the Kids," "Jumanji")Screenwriters: Peter Buchman, Alexander Payne and Jim TaylorCast: Sam Neill, William H. Macy, Tea Leoni, Alessandro Nivola, Trevor Morgan, Michael Jeter, John Diehl, Bruce A. Young, Laura Dern.Review: Steven Spielberg decided to relinquish the director's chair to Joe Johnston this time around, and opted to don his executive-producer hat instead. While Johnston lacks Spielberg's directorial flair, he certainly makes up for it with break-neck pacing, and after the lengthy `Lost World,' that was a welcomed decision. Thankfully, there is no dull or unnecessary filler in this one.Sam Neill returns as Dr. Grant, as he is financially persuaded by a rich businessman (Macy) to lead an aerial-expedition over site B, and ultimately, the plane lands on the restricted dinosaur island. This short and sweet sequel (clocks in a little over 80 minutes without closing credits) is an entertaining popcorn flick that uses some nice twists and turns with its characters, and an enhanced sense of humor to keep the film moving. This time around, unlike the previous two films, the T-Rex takes a backseat to the new dino on the block, the Spinosaurus. That alone does ponder the question, "where the hell was the Spinosaurus in `The Lost World'"? How could the biggest dinosaur go unnoticed?Aside from little nitpicks here or there, the action is full throttle in this sequel, and while certain visual effects aren't as seamless as they were in previous outings, this is still a surprisingly entertaining thrill ride that is an improvement over Part 2. The John Williams theme is still effective; the apocalyptic-like setting is top notch, and it was great to have the return of Dr. Grant and Dr. Sattler (Dern). And though their break-up is never addressed, at least the film was never bogged down with any sort of resentment or anger between the two characters. With that said, there are die hard "Jurassic Park" fans that do take issue with that, as well as the inclusion of the Spinosaurus, and the exclusion of John Hammond and/or Ian Malcolm characters. You can't please everyone, but as it stands, I for one, found this to be solid popcorn flick. Thumbs up for me.The Bonus FeaturesLike any good collection, you always crave some nice special features. Here, Universal do not disappoint as all three films get a nice treatment with a wide assortment of featurettes, commentaries, some deleted scenes, trailers, storyboards, and honestly, a host of other nifty features.

reviewText: What an entertaining family of films (not to be confused with "family films"). And with the release of Jurassic Park IV on the horizon (2008 directed by III's Johnston), picking up this trilogy for your collection is a no-brainer in order to get back into dino-fever.Jurassic Park is the film that brought dinosaur movies out of the stone age. The beasts aren't stop motion....They're real! For the filming of these flicks they actually cloned dinosaurs from dino DNA preserved in prehistoric amber! Alright, alright...they look real. Very real. The FX are brilliant in all three Jurassic Parks. And that's the real beauty of the trilogy...the dino FX.Jurassic Park stayed pretty true to Crichton's novel, which was perhaps the fastest I've ever read an entire book (apx 5 hours). I tore through it because it was so good. But there were definitely some impressionable scenes like the T-rex swimming in the river ("like an alligator!") and of course "the bird cage" (or was the bird cage not until The Lost World novel?) that were omitted. At least "the bird cage" made its appearance on film in III.The Lost World was the exact opposite of "true to the book". Spielberg lost it in The Lost World. He took a lot of liberties making it his own story. How do you leave out of the movie one of the biggest stars of the book: the color-changing, chameleon-like, man-eater, Carnotaurus? Thank goodness Crichton was still involved in the screenplay or who knows how much more the story would have been twisted for the big screen.Jurassic III introduced the mighty Spinosaurus and brought in the pterodactyls. reviewText: Many years had passed since my last viewing of the Jurassic Park movies, and my mind had buried their badness in favor of their goodness. So when the chance came to buy this blu-ray set inexpensively--the cover was worn, but the disks were perfect--I did.The original JURASSIC PARK has its merits, especially near the beginning of the movie, but it also has its demerits. Specifically, unconvincing moments that are disrespectful of the serious viewer. Reviewing it alone, I might give it three stars, maybe four.The second movie, THE LOST WORLD, is terrible: a long succession of unrealistic, implausible, and unconvincing sequences. Still, the beasties are nice to look at. Reviewed by itself = two stars.I watched JURASSIC PARK III on the day after I watched THE LOST WORLD (JP-II). Therefore I was expecting more of the same: disgusting unrealism. But the leading sequence--man and boy flying a parasail--is not bad. And then the camera switches to sequences in America, and--believe it or not--an actual story develops (as opposed to the wretched scripting and the exploitation of dinosaurs that characterize JP-II). Even as JP-III's events move to an airplane over the second dinosaur island, there continues to be development of story and characters. Indeed, contrary to what I never feel in JP-II, in JP-III I feel approval. JURASSIC PARK III is not perfect. Especially during the action sequences, you can nitpick against unrealistic moments. But there is so very much unrealism in JP-II, that the moments of unrealism in JP-III become minor and tolerable.The third movie redeems the set. Because of it and because of the impressive dinosaurs in all three, I give this set five stars.I am not capable of praying with honesty, but I can fervently HOPE that the fourth Jurassic Park movie looks to JP-III as its mentor, not JP-I and ESPECIALLY not JP-II.
summary: Exploitive sci-fi adventure, but Jurassic Park III is a good movie

reviewText: I had the older DVD trilogy of Jurassic Park.  Then, when the 3D version of JP came out in April 2013, I toyed with the idea of rebuying it that way.I did a lot of research and found that, yes the 3D is nice for those who want that and insist on it...HOWEVER...the "color timing" (color balance, rendition) is not as good as the 2011 release 2D Blu-Ray Trilogy version.To see what I'm talking about, go to YouTube and type in "Jurassic Park Blu Ray Side by Side comparison 1080p"This was enough to make the decision to me.MY EXACT VERSION:Since Amazon tends to lump a lot of movie reviews together, the version I purchased lists itself as:  Import All Regions USN widescreen DTS Surround.  UPC 5050582830767  Bookcase says: Universal 828 307 6 dot 11  Amazon: USIN B004KKXMSIPackage has absolutely NO mention of Dolby.My Import 2D version has subtitles in English and 5 other languages.It has (if you want to use it) a separate dubbing track in Japanese.  I never saw an option for Dolby to choose in Setup.  In my case, it didn't matter as my receiver decodes DTS.PICTURE:  Stunning (and I mean stunning).  Exceptional.  Color rendition is effortlessly spot-on.  You can't get it better than this.  Really.  When I see the helicopter flying to the island in the initial scene..it is so pristine and clear that I'm transfixed.  I lose myself in the story.  None of the technical stuff of the video or sound every get in the way of the story. It's that way throughout all of the movie.  The only slightly weak stuff(technical integration onscreen)is when Sam O'Neill and Laura Dern (actors) first see the dinosaurs in the rolling hills and the seen with Sam O'Neill and the kids feeding the bracchiosaurus in the trees.  But those two exceptions even certainly weren't "bad" - and they were short lived parts of the overall film.SOUND:  I played this using the English default DTS 7.1 surround.  The sound mix is * stunning and exceptional * even on my mid-quality 5.1 system.  Dialog was very clear, I did not have any desire to turn on subtitles.Note: the other languages French, etc are in 5.1 mix.Nerd / Techy stuff:  I have a 60" LG Plasma HDTV fed and Sony BDP-S790 Blu-Ray player.  The nexus of all my components is a Pioneer VSX-1021 receiver.  Audio is output to Panasonic 5.1 speaker setup (Two 3ft towers, 2 smaller side channel -- inexpensive speakers from an older system) augmented with a Definitive Technology center channel (nice $300.00 dialog speaker I upgraded to).  My Panasonic subwoofer is frankly nothing to write home about.  The other "Panny" speakers are decent.  The movie still sounds awesome.Side channel mix and spatial effect was quite immersing and remember I'm only using a 5.1 setup.  God knows how good it would be on a true 7.1 setup with a better subwoofer.  This here is your demonstration disc!  No matter, I enjoyed the movie greatly.  The source quality given is so good that it pushes through and makes my system shine.I have the belief that this movie was transferred on a spare-no-expense budget as a labor of love by geeks with the best bleeding-edge equipment.SUMMARY:  Take my review with this grain of salt:  3D is not a big deal to me.  Frankly it's an annoyance. I never use the 3D feature even though my TV supports it. What * IS * a big deal to me is good color rendition, audio clarity and a naturally sharp picture without artifacts.  THIS IS IT !!!!If you go with purchasing the other, latest release, 3D version,.. realize that you will be gaining the 3D effect at the possible expense of having to put up with an overly tweaked color balance that is possibly inferior to this 2D version. (i.e. it may have an strong orange / teal cast).  To each his own, your call.
summary: Blu-Ray 2D Trilogy has stunning visual quality and color rendition
